questions.question: A grandparent’s job is easier than ………………………….
questions.description: When we make comparisons both nouns should be in the same case. Since the first noun is in the possessive case here, the second noun too should be in the possessive case. We can make a possessive form by adding apostrophe s or with the structure that/those of.

questions.question: Take your coat and pass me …………………………...
questions.description: We cannot use one immediately after my.

questions.question: Do you think Trollope’s novels are more entertaining than ……………………………..?
questions.description: ‘Those of Dickens’ itself is a possessive term.

questions.question: …………………………. you have passed your test, I will give you a job.
questions.description: Once can mean after or as soon as

questions.question: We can go for a walk ……………………………. the rain has stopped.
questions.description: We cannot use that after once.

questions.question: Not only …………………………. clothing, but they are also short of medicine.
questions.description: When not only comes at the beginning, it is followed by an inverted word order. That means the auxiliary goes before the subject.

questions.question: I haven’t bought you ……………………….
questions.description: We do not normally use something in negative clauses.

questions.question: ………………………….., he failed the test.
questions.description: We use not to make a clause negative.

questions.question: Call me when you arrive ……………………………. late it is.
questions.description: No matter how means the same as however.

questions.question: …………………………… you say, I won’t believe you.
questions.description: No matter what means the same as whatever.

questions.question: I …………………………….. support the congress party.
questions.description: We do not use no more to mean that an action or situation has stopped.

questions.question: …………………………. helped me when I was in trouble.
questions.description: No one means not any one.
